response.answer_text: Not really. There would have been no time at which he didn’t have a reasonably good idea where he was, or at least as good an idea as one could have before a reliable way of measuring longitude was invented. He had solid ideas of how far north or south he was and which direction he was headed, and probably an approximate idea of his speed. The problem wasn’t that he didn’t know where he was. It was that he really didn’t understand where he was going. Or what there was to see along the way. His estimate of the circumference of the Earth was too small, and he was unaware of a big-ass continent being in the way.

Can you get lost if you don't know where are you going? :) Seriously, there's plenty of debate about how much he actually knew about the Indies, but it is clear that the Crown funded the expedition based on intelligence obtained/stolen from Basque fishermen and the Portuguese. So, even if he didn't actually know where exactly he was going, he knew there was something. It was not entirely an expedition into the unknown. Around the Antilles, he indeed was in exploratory mode: Getting 'lost' and finding out what was there was the idea.

He did. He was aiming for Japan or China. Instead he “found” the Caribbean (It was there and populated all the time and the locals never thought they had been lost) but on his second voyage he still never found what is now North America. By the time of his third voyage North America had been “discovered” by a certain Mr Cabot, from Bristol, on a voyage paid for by a Mr Americ. This is why the continent or continents if you prefere, are called America and not either Columbia or after his benefactors. Countries are named after the Discoverer, the Discoverers Monarch or paymaster. If the country has a population regarded as “civilised” then the rest of the world, or at least the bits that matter as far as they are concerned, tended to go along with their name of their home. Oh and it is generally agreed that the lads from Norway got there first, around the 1100’s and set up home for about 100 years.

It's what we call serendipity. Chris really had sheer dumb luck. He followed charts made by Toscanelli who mistakenly calculated that Asia was 5k miles/c.8000km wider. Columbus mistakenly underestimated the Earth's circumference by 25%.

Yep he did the dotto thought he was going to Asia. After months at sea his crew was about to kill him and turn back and go home. Soon they just happened to stumble across the islands in the Caribbean Sea. The ones they were not looking for.
